views.title: Document
views.content: {"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Codename Vault is a combination of a note-taking app and task management."}]},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"In the explorer, you have folders and notes. A note can have multiple views, such as “Document”, which is a text editor. “Board”, which is a kanban board with tasks, each with their own text editor and properties. “Canvas”, an implementation of TLDraw."}]}]}

views.title: New Board
views.content:
{"columns":[{"id":"932d380b-3149-41fd-ac2d-5eff079ee99d","title":"Future versions","tasks":[{"id":"6fee07b5-fb6a-40ff-936f-a9e3332a9995","content":"Back and forward support","detail":"

"},{"id":"a5c7c177-f546-4525-9cbc-f24c15ad2def","content":"Zoom in or out","detail":"

"},{"id":"3e220d57-72b1-4bdf-87e9-cafa6aa9a3b6","content":"Item shortcuts","detail":"

Essentially have a shortcut to an item. This allows you to have an item appear multiple times in the explorer. Which were the main benefits of using the tag tree in Obsidian

"},{"id":"8f13972f-e6b3-484b-99b6-3cc6a58d3e34","content":"Tag icon metadata","detail":"

Give a tag a custom icon? Not sure how this would look like in the UI

"},{"id":"f3d06efc-4a46-420c-91be-994de9798332","content":"Query Collections","detail":"

This is a dropdown menu in the sidebar, similar to a vault, but in the global section. Adding a collection create a query text field. You fill it, and the collection will create a tree of all items that match the query.

This is very low priority. It's more or less a wacky idea I had

"},{"id":"c612628c-7210-47dd-b221-07a4b6cb5f04","content":"Web view","detail":"

Basically, I want to be able to have my discord server attached to this app.
This would be a global view

"},{"id":"dd548fd6-0333-4eba-8076-a2f07a1fdd00","content":"Tasks and tag automation","detail":"

I would love for columns to automatically add a tag to a task when a task is added to it, and automatically remove a tag when a task is removed from it.

This would allow you to create columns like \"Todo\", \"In Progress\" and \"Completed\". These columns would automatically add and remove \"Status.Todo\", \"Status.InProgress\" and \"Status.Completed\" to tasks.

This would be a great feature for queries, since tasks would now automatically be able to tell the query system through tags whether they are in progress or not.

The current problem is: How to solve this in the UI.

"},{"id":"a0fe951a-decd-4992-a434-1b3eee08d719","content":"Journal View","detail":"

Basically the journal type from Thymer. I'm considering making this a global thing, managing multiple journals sounds annoying

"}]},{"id":"94f48600-6459-41ae-85de-1341b3d36f3e","title":"To-do","tasks":[{"id":"0957b2cf-b716-494f-b95d-00596e3db492","content":"Timeline view","detail":"

"},{"id":"3c2b4e37-6ec6-4f64-9ac7-38f88e583d6c","content":"Better keyboard support/navigation","detail":"

Some minor details such as:

  1. Making a task, then pressing enter while in the description field should automatically press \"Save Changes\" for you

  2. When naming a task, pressing enter should navigate you to the description field

"},{"id":"aec3b298-cc7c-430e-a193-d388070f933c","content":"\"Word library\" component","detail":"

There's going to be multiple areas where you're going to have word-sensitive fields (properties, board column names, queries, word highlighting feature we have yet to name, etc).

This has a lot of overlap between this goal:

A list of keywords that when written, will automatically have the word styled. The use-case for this is that I like to color my documentation. Variables are purple, classes are yellow, functions are red, etc.

  • Bonus points: Folder selection tool that when given a Unreal Engine project or plugin, will automatically scan the codebase and find all functions and properties and automatically add them to this list.

    • This needs to be processed in the background so we don't freeze the app while this processing is happening. Some projects have huge codebases

    • Might be simpler to just have this script treat any header/cpp file the same, doesn't have to be a Unreal Engine project or plugin, it just extracts everything it considers a function and variable

      • It might have Unreal Engine specific features. Like a UPROPERTY variable would list the category it's in, if it's BlueprintReadWrite and so forth

    • Bonus bonus points: The styling is a hoverable block, like a mention, and when hovered it shows you some metadata from this global list. For example; the class or struct that a variable can be found in. A folder path string for a class

"},{"id":"be340551-51d5-4313-8a6d-96557d5e5f03","content":"Hover sidebar sticks when cursor leaves app","detail":"

If the cursor is not inside the app, the sidebar should slide away after a short period

"},{"id":"2ea4ca75-6ca4-46b0-a0ab-a3f44e646662","content":"Tag Priority metadata","detail":"

Controls the order in which tags are displayed

  • Default is 0

  • All tags with the same value are organized alphabetically

  • Higher priority means higher in the list. Allowed to go into the negatives

"},{"id":"d79447f9-f0d5-4b75-9bbb-e684c273102d","content":"Close vaults tabs when disconnecting","detail":"

When disconnecting a vault, the tabs related to it should be closed

"},{"id":"1181dcf5-0280-475c-9591-bd9e414b43b6","content":"Fix kanban board hitboxes","detail":"

When dragging a task into an empty column, it's really hard

"},{"id":"daca845d-3b11-4e6f-98c9-7a506ae4bdc9","content":"Query system","detail":"

Before we move onto things like live queries and query collections, we need to create a prototype of this query system.

Syntax

I see the syntax going something like this:

Type:Task, HasTagExact(@Status.Todo), User:Varian

This would provide all tasks with the @Status.Todo tag, with Varian assigned as the user

The UI

We will begin by implementing this inside the CTRL+P menu (Command menu), where you can manually type in a query

"},{"id":"73b222f8-b469-4812-b7d6-9a9d5959a2b2","content":"Command menu","detail":"

This is the CTRL + P menu.

This brings up a search bar in the middle of the app. Below the search bar are suggestions as you type (Suggestions). Above the bar are your previous uses (History). For example, if I search \"My aweso\" as incomplete text, the suggestions will show \"My awesome note\". If I use the down arrow, I can select the \"My awesome note\" suggestion and open the note. Now, that \"My awesome note\" will appear above the search bar next time I open this menu, letting me quickly select it by using the up arrow.

If the typed out text is a query, then the suggestions turn into all the items that fulfil that query.
For example, typing \"Type(Task), HasTag(@Status.Todo), User(Varian)\", then the suggestions will show all tasks with the Status.Todo tag and mention the \"Varian\" user.

After using a query, it goes into the \"History\" section. If you scroll up and press enter on a query, it doesn't try to \"open it\" or something like it would for things like notes. Instead, it replaces the text in the search bar with that query text, so the suggestions update

"},{"id":"feabb290-8403-46ce-a52b-c3bd2f8aac10","content":"Fix tags not duplicating when referenced in another vault","detail":"

referencing tags in text is for some reason working, but isn't duplicating the tag. The properties section can not reference the tag nor duplicate it

"}]},{"id":"b5624773-b7fe-4232-9203-1c66e589092e","title":"In Progress","tasks":[{"id":"eea546e7-e813-47e2-9802-6ea7bb9004d9","content":"Restyle app","detail":"

Design Directive: \"Nostromo Industrial\"

Core Philosophy:

The UI should feel like a piece of heavy machinery or a ship's diagnostic terminal. It is utilitarian, high-contrast, and dense. It avoids \"soft\" modern web trends (rounded corners, soft drop shadows, blur glass) in favor of harsh lines, grids, and raw data visualization. It blends the \"Cassette Futurism\" of the Alien franchise with modern \"Industrial Brutalism\".

1. Visual Language & Shape

* Strict Grid System: All layouts must be defined by visible 1px borders. The screen should look like a blueprint or a schematics board.

* Corner Bracketing: Active panels or inputs should use \"bracketed\" corners (framed corners that don't fully enclose the element) rather than standard borders.

* No Border Radius: All corners are sharp (0px) or chamfered (45-degree cuts). No rounded corners.

* Decoration: Use \"Technical debris\" — ruler marks, crosshairs, and serial numbers (e.g., SYS-01, V.202) decorative elements in the corners of containers.

2. Color Palette (Cyberpunk Red Adaptation)

* Backgrounds: Void Black (#050505) to Deep Gunmetal (#0a0a0a). High contrast.

* Surface: \"Monitor Grey\" (#111111) for cards/panels.

* Accents:

* Primary: Cyberpunk Red (#c53e35) - Used for errors, critical alerts, and active states.

* Secondary: Amber/Orange (#ff9900) or Terminal Green (#33ff00) - Used for success states or graph lines.

* Text: Off-white (#eeeeee) for readability, dimmed grey (#666666) for metadata.

3. The \"Dither\" & Texture Effect

* Dithering: Use a 1px checkerboard or Bayer dither pattern as a background texture for:

* Empty states.

* Inactive/Disabled buttons.

* \"Graph\" backgrounds.

* Scanlines: Subtle horizontal scanline overlays on the entire app or specific video/image containers (using pointer-events: none).

* Animation: \"Glitch\" or \"Step\" animations. Transitions should be snappy (mechanical), not smooth/floaty.

4. Typography

* Font: Keep JetBrains Mono.

* Uppercase: Use uppercase text for headers, labels, and button text to simulate terminal readouts.

* Hierarchy: Use font weight and opacity for hierarchy, not size. Keep text relatively small and dense.

"}]},{"id":"7cbbacea-62dc-4c1d-a88b-254ef7593b7e","title":"Completed","tasks":[{"id":"06ae7b46-ece5-4452-8e23-8bf4851bc7f0","content":"Tag Properties","detail":"

We'll be beginning with just tags. My dream would be to have it work like gameplay tags, so we can do queries like gameplay tag queries (though we will just be doing queries through pure text)

Tags

  • Look and behave very similar to gameplay tags from Unreal engine.

    • The big goal is that when we implement a query system, we can add a similar query system to Gameplay Tag Queries.

  • Our tags will get 1 added feature to them, and that's metadata. Such as color and display name. We'll be beginning with just color and display name, but the foundation has to keep in mind that more can be added later.

    • We will be labelling some metadata as inheritable by children tags. Such as color, not display name

  • The tag UI looks similar to the gameplay tags selector UI in Unreal Engine, but with 1 added feature; vault filtering. All tags are stored inside the database per vault. So when you share a vault, all the tags that vault is using come with it. But if you don't want to see tags from VaultA when you're in VaultB, then you can just toggle VaultA's tags in the filter dropdown.

    • If you add a tag to something inside of VaultB, but that tag originates in VaultA and doesn't exist in VaultB, then that tag is automatically added to VaultB's database. It also copies all the metadata from the tag.

      • If two tags with the same name, but with different metadata is found, then they are not combined in the UI and are treated as 2 different tags. TLDR; tags must be 100% identical, down to the metadata, to be combined in the dropdown menu. If they aren't 100% identical, they appear as 2 different tags, even though they might have identical names

  • Tags can be referenced in the TipTap text editor, like a mention. The syntax for this is not yet decided

"},{"id":"e178f61e-2b65-499e-ae41-e5fd10f7da29","content":"Tabs getting disconnected","detail":"

When switching between vaults, tabs with notes from unopened vaults are unable to load if refreshed, like the server can't connect to them

"}]},{"id":"4f238d59-078d-41b7-b077-11ef6171b27a","title":"Will not support or implement","tasks":[]}]}

views.title: Document
views.content: {"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Any database is only useful if it has useful queries."}]}]}

views.title: Document
views.content: {"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"I come from a Unreal Engine background. In that engine, there are “gameplay tags”. This feature is in my opinion, the best tag system in any piece of software I’ve used."}]},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Due to this, I have essentially copied the feature, but sprinkled some extra features. This includes colors, tooltips, name lengths, tooltips, basically any metadata I want to grant them."}]},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Tags are primarily attached to notes and tasks through the properties section below the title text."}]},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"But that’s not the only place tags can be used… They can be put in text like so: "},{"type":"tagMention","attrs":{"id":"7c109b40-33c4-438f-b66c-8e8443d8ea85","label":"Foo.Bar","color":"#2f3438","type":"tag"}},{"type":"text","text":" (Can you find the secret tooltip?)"}]},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"tagMention","attrs":{"id":"e6d8133d-8882-4cf5-a918-65be95839396","label":"Foo","color":"#682c2c","type":"tag"}},{"type":"text","text":" test"}]}]}

views.title: Document
views.content: {"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","marks":[{"type":"code"}],"text":"Level Architect"},{"type":"text","text":" is a level design plugin."}]}]}
